description: Probably of North Germanic origin, from Norwegian flunsa (“hurry”), perhaps ultimately imitative.  Or, perhaps formed on the pattern of pounce, bounce.

entries.meaning: (sewing) A strip of decorative material, usually pleated, attached along one edge; a ruffle.W
A row of spines, corrugations, or skin folds on the hemipenis of a snake.

verbs.description: flounce (third-person singular simple present flounces, present participle flouncing, simple past and past participle flounced)

entries.meaning: To move in an exaggerated, bouncy manner.
(archaic) To flounder; to make spastic motions.
examples: With his broad fins and forky tail he laves / The rising surge, and flounces in the waves.

entries.meaning: To depart in a haughty, dramatic way that draws attention to oneself.
examples: After failing to win the leadership election, he flounced dramatically.
